Ten hours into Pfizer shot #2. Arm barely sore and no other symptoms so far. I even did 80 minutes of cardio this evening. Starve this virus of its hosts. Just Do It!
@AStillwellPhD @MichaelEWebber @energymovies OK --- I am going to get on board. The next indoor air quality class that I teach will end with a discussion of "Air At the Movies".

@futureproofr I hope not. I have so many wonderful long-time friends in Ontario and east and know how difficult things have been there wrt vaccines. Keep your guard up, @futureproofr. It's a good life if you don't weaken.
@JimRosenthal4 @Jan_KraakSD You rock, Jim!

Shortly after Pfizer Shot #2! I always wear my old #TragicallyHip mission cap for big events, and this one qualified. But the nose is what got many comments in line and from staff. Doing my part to starve this virus of its hosts, and maybe create a few smiles along the way. https://t.co/2z1twQCs3X

Off for Pfizer shot #2! Just did another half-Milton shave to get a good fit of mask on face. And yes, I will be wearing my clown nose on mask to celebrate this day with others getting vaccinated as we do our collective part to starve this virus of its hosts. Just do it! https://t.co/yGRLIwQmyk

A standard polyurethane foam clown nose stays securely on my mask if air gaps around the crease of my nose are effectively minimized and pops off otherwise. It has the added benefit of entertaining other shoppers. No clowning around. https://t.co/vzeycpaGUa
Bingo. https://t.co/t8dUDs7YVs

Really excited about doing my part to starve SARS-CoV-2 its many variants from its hosts. Pfizer shot #2 tomorrow. Bring it on! Razor at the ready for a good morning shave to assure a proper mask fit. Just Doin' It!
Patriotic: "Having or expressing devotion to and vigorous support for one's country." Get vaccinated. Just do it!
@edyong209 Typo. What a great name! Beautiful dog. Looks like a cattle dog/Corgi mix.

Just read a paper on a specific electronic air "cleaning" device w/ a "low emission rate" of ozone that is so high it is roughly equal to moving a home from an area of pristine air quality on the Oregon coast to amongst the most ozone-polluted cities in US. Just (don't) do it!
And thank you as well, @polsiewski. You have been a great facilitator, communicator, and leader on this issue. https://t.co/UzSNdvjn2e

2/ Whatever the reason, humankind has not fared well in its wake. The reason we should not allow history to be rewritten is so that those who can make a major difference from the start do NOT repeat their mistakes next time.

1/ I agree 100% w/ @jljcolorado. Many of us saw the importance of transmission by aerosols in both the near and far fields early in this pandemic. Those who mattered were not qualified to understand transmission by aerosols, wearing blinders, or worse. https://t.co/QuGqSWr9Yl

@TechKev @linseymarr Thanks, @TechKev. Nothing was complicated back then. It did make perfect sense and was so frustrating that those who really mattered could not see it and did not do their part to save us from where the world has gotten.

@marinavance I know. News on Brazil has somehow been lost due to the devastation occurring in India. But it too continues to be ravaged. Horrible, failed, belligerent, IMO criminal "leadership" has led to a humanitarian crisis.

@akm5376 I agree. India, Brazil, other countries/regions should never have gotten to this place of devastation, loss, sorrow, death, and suffering. Too much of the world lacked leadership and "authorities" wore thick blinders, refusing to take them off - to the detriment of humankind.

Slow learners and sad that it took 14 months (and likely devastation of India) to come around to what has been obvious to so many for so long. Let's hope that this recognition has some benefit moving forward. https://t.co/ffA64qtlRZ
@wennbergcaltech I know. But that does not stop me from being a grumpy old engineer. :)
@DavidElfstrom @healthyheating Ditto on all fronts.

@JulietteBrod101 Depends on the size and amount of openings, outdoor wind speeds and direction relative to openings on building ( whether fans are used in openings). Did expts on my own garage with door open. Typically achieved 15 to 25 air changes per hour w/o fans.

The Computer Science program in the Maseeh College of Engineering Computer Science has an excellent cybersecurity group, cybersecurity graduate certificate, and award winning student team in Capture The Flag competitions. Check out this panel discussion! https://t.co/V2e4slfncR

@tomgillpredicts Interesting. I have been called for jury duty 3 or 4 times. Every time I have been the first person excused during jury selection. It's gotten to the point where I feel bad about always being so quickly rejected!

9/ The way to do it is to GET FULLY VACCINATED, wear a mask when not eating, minimize time in space (take out best) for restaurants to increase ventilation use one or more of: advanced central filtration, HEPA filtration systems, appropriate upper-room UVGI.

8/ I am still not a fan of going to indoor restaurants right now because of the need to remove mask because some (many?) will not be fully vaccinated. But the way to substantially reduce COVID-19 infection is not with barriers that (on average) have a minimal (if any) effect.

7/ In that context, it would probably be more effective to put patches of carpet on walls or fleecy materials hung from the ceiling to increase particle decay rate to materials with large surface areas (which I am not advocating).

6/ It does not appear to me that these barriers constitute more than a few % of the total surface area in the space (including walls, floor, ceiling, furnishings, people when present) and would therefore lower particle decay rates by a tiny amount.
5/ Assuming that the barriers do not affect volume or deposition velocity (they might affect mixing and therefore could affect vd to some extent), then the key parameter is surface area, A.

4/ k = vd x (A/V). vd is a deposition velocity, which is a function of particle diam, mixing conditions in bulk air, friction velocity near surface, and more. A = surface area. V = volume of interior space.

3/ Is there a benefit in terms of far field exposure? Very minimal. Here's why. Indoor aerosol particle decay rates (k) to (integrated) indoor surfaces range from approx 0.2 to 10/hr for 0.3 to 10 um particles, respectively (higher for larger diameter particles).
2/ The risk of people letting their guards down thinking that barriers are somehow effective for aerosol particles is much greater than any benefit, IMHO. Technical answer next.

1/ Simple answer = very little for aerosol particles but possibly (in some cases) dispersion that reduces close contact dose. But depending on flow conditions, there can be a low pressure zone on the downstream side that leads to some accumulation of particles. https://t.co/FpZMabEsNk

Pet peeves (still old school): "Particulates" as a noun. No! No! No! No! No! "Particulate matter" I don't care what any dictionary says, "particulate" is an adjective. Probably a lost cause, but I still cringe when I hear "Data is". A "data point is". "Data are".

For the 9,999th time, plants may look nice but they remove no more than minuscule (not measurable) amounts of VOCs etc. from indoor air. The amount of plants necessary to remove measurable amounts would cause many other problems. https://t.co/QE0DMLyqrE

@JATetro My modeling of outbreaks suggests a cumulative deposited particle volume of as little as 1 to 10 picoliters of PM4 has caused infections. That's total deposition in respiratory system. For nose breathers, approx 75% in nasopharyngeal, 20% in alv, 5% in TB.

2/ At one time they were all PhD students or post-docs (@poppendieck) in our indoor air quality program @ut_caee. And that's just a start of a much longer list of our grads who are doing will keep doing great things in the IAQ field! Super proud of all + their advisors.
